Universality of an impurity in a Bose-Einstein condensate

Shuhei M. Yoshida Department of Physics, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo 113-0033, Japan School of Physics and Astronomy, Monash University, Victoria 3800, Australia â€ƒâ€ƒ Shimpei Endo School of Physics and Astronomy, Monash University, Victoria 3800, Australia â€ƒâ€ƒ Jesper Levinsen School of Physics and Astronomy, Monash University, Victoria 3800, Australia â€ƒâ€ƒ Meera M.Â Parish School of Physics and Astronomy, Monash University, Victoria 3800, Australia
Abstract

Universality is a powerful concept in physics, allowing one to construct physical descriptions of systems that are independent of the precise microscopic details or energy scales. A prime example is the Fermi gas with unitarity limited interactions, whose universal properties are relevant to systems ranging from atomic gases at microkelvin temperatures to the inner crust of neutron stars. Here we address the question of whether unitary Bose systems can possess a similar universality. We consider the simplest strongly interacting Bose system, where we have an impurity particle (â€œpolaronâ€) resonantly interacting with a Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC). Focusing on the ground state of the equal-mass system, we use a variational wave function for the polaron that includes up to three Bogoliubov excitations of the BEC, thus allowing us to capture both Efimov trimers and associated tetramers. Unlike the Fermi case, we find that the length scale associated with Efimov trimers (i.e., the three-body parameter) can strongly affect the polaronâ€™s behaviour, even at boson densities where there are no well-defined Efimov states. However, by comparing our results with recent quantum Monte Carlo calculations, we argue that the polaron energy is a universal function of the Efimov three-body parameter for sufficiently low boson densities. We further support this conclusion by showing that the energies of the deepest bound Efimov trimers and tetramers at unitarity are universally related to one another, regardless of the microscopic model. On the other hand, we find that the quasiparticle residue and effective mass sensitively depend on the coherence length Î¾ğœ‰\xi of the BEC, with the residue tending to zero as Î¾ğœ‰\xi diverges, in a manner akin to the orthogonality catastrophe.

I Introduction

Quantum gases are expected to exhibit universal thermodynamic and dynamical properties when the scattering length aâ†’Â±âˆâ†’ğ‘plus-or-minusa\to\pm\infty and the interparticle spacing greatly exceeds the range of the interactions. Here, the large separation of length scales implies that the unitary gas is independent of an interaction length scale, thus making it insensitive to its microscopic properties. This scenario exists for the two-component Fermi gas at unitarityÂ RanderiaÂ etÂ al. (2012), where highly controlled cold-atom experiments have recently determined its universal equation of state KuÂ etÂ al. (2012); NascimbÃ¨neÂ etÂ al. (2010); HorikoshiÂ etÂ al. (2010), pairing correlations PartridgeÂ etÂ al. (2005); StewartÂ etÂ al. (2008); SchirotzekÂ etÂ al. (2008); InadaÂ etÂ al. (2008); VeeravalliÂ etÂ al. (2008); NavonÂ etÂ al. (2010); StewartÂ etÂ al. (2010); KuhnleÂ etÂ al. (2010) and transport properties CaoÂ etÂ al. (2011). Moreover, Bose gases in the unitary regime are now also being experimentally probed using ultracold atomic gases MakotynÂ etÂ al. (2014); HuÂ etÂ al. (2016); JÃ¸rgensenÂ etÂ al. (2016); FletcherÂ etÂ al. (2017); LopesÂ etÂ al. (2017); KlaussÂ etÂ al. (2017); EigenÂ etÂ al. (2017). However, it remains an open question whether the unitary Bose system can also display universal behavior that has relevance to a range of different physical systems.

In contrast to the Fermi case, bosonic systems at unitarity always support few-body Efimov bound statesÂ Efimov (1970); BraatenÂ andÂ Hammer (2006); KraemerÂ etÂ al. (2006); NaidonÂ andÂ Endo (2017); GreeneÂ etÂ al. (2017); Dâ€™Incao (2017), whose energy and size depend on short-distance parameters such as the interaction range rğ‘Ÿr. Thus, there is an additional interaction length scale that can impact the behavior of the unitary Bose system and potentially make it sensitive to microscopic details. Indeed, the deepest bound trimers and larger few-body clusters typically cannot be universally related to each other without invoking a specific model for the short-range interactionsÂ NaidonÂ andÂ Endo (2017); GreeneÂ etÂ al. (2017).

To investigate the universality of a Bose system at unitarity, we consider an impurity immersed in a Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC), where the boson-impurity interactions can be tuned to unitarity, while the rest of the system remains weakly interacting. This so-called â€œBose polaronâ€ has received much theoretical attentionÂ TempereÂ etÂ al. (2009); RathÂ andÂ Schmidt (2013); LiÂ andÂ DasÂ Sarma (2014); ShashiÂ etÂ al. (2014); ChristensenÂ etÂ al. (2015); LevinsenÂ etÂ al. (2015); PeÃ±a ArdilaÂ andÂ Giorgini (2015); GrusdtÂ etÂ al. (2015); GrusdtÂ andÂ Demler (2015); PeÃ±a ArdilaÂ andÂ Giorgini (2016); ShchadilovaÂ etÂ al. (2016a); LoftÂ etÂ al. (2017); GrusdtÂ etÂ al. (2017); SunÂ etÂ al. (2017); LampoÂ etÂ al. (2017) and has very recently been observed in cold-atom experimentsÂ HuÂ etÂ al. (2016); JÃ¸rgensenÂ etÂ al. (2016). Moreover, it has been extended to impurities with more complex internal structureÂ SchmidtÂ andÂ Lemeshko (2015); SchmidtÂ etÂ al. (2016); CamargoÂ etÂ al. (2017), and it has potential relevance to polaron problems in solid-state systems â€” for instance, the limit of weak impurity-boson interactions can be directly mapped to the FrÃ¶hlich model TempereÂ etÂ al. (2009); RentropÂ etÂ al. (2016). The Bose polaron is a promising system in which to search for universal behavior, since the Efimov trimers consisting of the impurity and two bosons are orders of magnitude larger than the short distance scale rğ‘Ÿr (provided the impurity mass is not too small)Â WangÂ etÂ al. (2012a); BlumeÂ andÂ Yan (2014). If we parameterize the size of the deepest Efimov trimer by |aâˆ’|subscriptğ‘|a_{-}|, where aâˆ’subscriptğ‘a_{-} is the scattering length at which the trimer crosses the three-atom continuum (see Fig.Â 1), then the hierarchy of length scales at unitarity is râ‰ªnâˆ’1/3â‰ª|aâˆ’|much-less-thanğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘›13much-less-thansubscriptğ‘r\ll n^{-1/3}\ll|a_{-}| for the typical densities nğ‘›n in experimentÂ HuÂ etÂ al. (2016); JÃ¸rgensenÂ etÂ al. (2016). This suggests that there is a regime where Efimov physics is irrelevant, such that the ground-state properties of the polaron only depend on the density, like in the case of an impurity resonantly interacting with a Fermi gasÂ Chevy (2006); CombescotÂ andÂ Giraud (2008); Prokofâ€™evÂ andÂ Svistunov (2008); VlietinckÂ etÂ al. (2013); MassignanÂ etÂ al. (2014).

In this paper, we address this question using impurities that have a mass equal to that of the bosons â€” a situation which has already been realized in the 39K atomic gas experiments in Aarhus JÃ¸rgensenÂ etÂ al. (2016). We first investigate the few-body limit, and determine the Efimov trimer and associated tetramer states that involve the impurity. For vanishing boson-boson interactions, we show that the ratios of the binding energies for the deepest bound states are universal, unlike the identical-boson case. We then include this Efimov physics in the many-body system by constructing a variational wave function for the ground-state Bose polaron which recovers both three- and four-body equations in the limit of zero density. Strikingly, we find that the polaron properties at unitarity sensitively depend on the Efimov scale |aâˆ’|subscriptğ‘|a_{-}|, even in the regime where |aâˆ’|subscriptğ‘|a_{-}| far exceeds the interparticle spacing. However, we show that the ground-state polaron energy is a universal function of n1/3â€‹|aâˆ’|superscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘n^{1/3}|a_{-}| that is model independent in the regime n1/3â€‹râ‰ª1much-less-thansuperscriptğ‘›13ğ‘Ÿ1n^{1/3}r\ll 1. We corroborate this finding by comparing our results with recent quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) calculations PeÃ±a ArdilaÂ andÂ Giorgini (2015, 2016).

In the non-universal, high-density limit n1/3â€‹râ‰«1much-greater-thansuperscriptğ‘›13ğ‘Ÿ1n^{1/3}r\gg 1, we consider the case of a narrow Feshbach resonance and we derive perturbative expressions for the polaron energy and contact at unitarity. This allows us to demonstrate, for the first time, that the Bose polaron at unitarity can be thermodynamically stable even in the limit of vanishing boson-boson interactions. On the other hand, we find that the quasiparticle residue and effective mass sensitively depend on the BEC coherence length. For the case of an ideal BEC, the effective mass converges to a finite value as we increase the number of excitations of the condensate, while the residue vanishes in a manner reminiscent of the orthogonality catastrophe for a static impurity in a Fermi gasÂ Anderson (1967).

II Model and variational approach

We consider an impurity atom immersed in a weakly interacting homogeneous Bose-Einstein condensate at zero temperature. The interactions in the medium are characterised by the boson-boson scattering length aBsubscriptğ‘Ba_{\text{B}}, and we thus require n0â€‹aB3â‰ª1much-less-thansubscriptğ‘›0superscriptsubscriptğ‘B31n_{0}a_{\text{B}}^{3}\ll 1, with n0subscriptğ‘›0n_{0} the condensate density (which essentially equals the total density nğ‘›n in this regime). This allows us to treat both the ground state and the excitations of the BEC within Bogoliubov theoryÂ FetterÂ andÂ Walecka (1971). Note that we always implicitly assume aB>0subscriptğ‘B0a_{\text{B}}>0 to ensure the stability of the condensate.

The presence of the impurity in the medium adds two length scales associated with the impurity-boson interaction. The first of these is the scattering length ağ‘a between the impurity and a boson from the medium. We disregard this length scale since we will focus on the strong-coupling unitary regime close to a Feshbach resonance, where |a|ğ‘|a| greatly exceeds all other length scales, i.e., we generally consider 1/a=01ğ‘01/a=0. Here, we assume short-range contact interactions, which is well realized in current cold-atom experiments.

The second additional length scale is the so-called three-body parameter, which characterizes the size of the smallest (ground-state) Efimov trimer consisting of two bosons and the impurity. To demonstrate the model independence of our results, we fix this Efimov length scale in two different ways:

    r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0r_{0}-model â€” we introduce an effective range r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0r_{0}, which directly relates the three-body parameter to the two-body interactionÂ Petrov (2004)

    Î›Î›\Lambda-model â€” we take r0â†’0â†’subscriptğ‘Ÿ00r_{0}\to 0 and instead apply an explicit ultraviolet cutoff Î›Î›\Lambda to the momenta involved in Efimov physics, which is equivalent to including a three-body repulsionÂ BedaqueÂ etÂ al. (1999)

As we explicitly show in SectionÂ III, for an impurity of the same mass as the medium atoms â€” the scenario considered here â€” the precise manner of regularizing Efimov physics is unimportant owing to the large separation of scales between the short-range physics and Efimov physics.

III Universal few-body Efimov states

Before proceeding to the many-body polaron physics, it is important to first discuss the few-body limit since â€” as we shall explicitly demonstrate in SectionÂ IV â€” this plays a crucial role in understanding the polaron properties. To determine the few-body spectrum, we use wave functions of the form (5) in the limit nâ†’0â†’ğ‘›0n\to 0, such that |Î¦âŸ©ketÎ¦\left|{\Phi}\right> now corresponds to the Fock vacuum. Here, the state |ÏˆNâŸ©ketsubscriptğœ“ğ‘\left|{\psi_{N}}\right> with Nğ‘N excitations is identified as a few-body state containing Nğ‘N bosons and the impurity. Consequently, the varational approach is exact and the sectors of different particle numbers completely decouple. Ignoring the trivial equation arising from the single-particle problem, the resulting few-body equations take the form

as found by solving Eq.Â (6). The three-body problem described by Eq.Â (7) is distinctly different: For strong interactions, the impurity and two bosons can form an infinite series of three-body bound states, even in the absence of the two-body bound state. Remarkably, these so-called Efimov trimersÂ Efimov (1970, 1973) satisfy a discrete scaling symmetry whereby the energy Eğ¸E of one trimer can be mapped onto the next via the discrete transformation Eâ†’Î»0âˆ’2â€‹lâ€‹Eâ†’ğ¸superscriptsubscriptğœ†02ğ‘™ğ¸E\to\lambda_{0}^{-2l}E and aâ†’Î»0lâ€‹aâ†’ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ†0ğ‘™ğ‘a\to\lambda_{0}^{l}a, with lğ‘™l integer and Î»0subscriptğœ†0\lambda_{0} a scaling parameter that depends on the particular three-body problem (for reviews, see Refs.Â BraatenÂ andÂ Hammer (2006); NaidonÂ andÂ Endo (2017); GreeneÂ etÂ al. (2017); Dâ€™Incao (2017)). In our case of two non-interacting identical bosons with the same mass as the third particle, the scaling factor is found from a transcendental equation to be Î»0=eÏ€/s0â‰ƒ1986.1subscriptğœ†0superscriptğ‘’ğœ‹subscriptğ‘ 0similar-to-or-equals1986.1\lambda_{0}=e^{\pi/s_{0}}\simeq 1986.1Â Efimov (1973). Due to this large scaling factor, we only show the two lowest trimer states in the figure (indeed, for realistic experimental parameters, the size of the first excited Efimov trimer is of order 1cm!).

Below the ground-state Efimov trimer, we predict the existence of two tetramer states, even at unitarity (see Fig.Â 1). This mirrors previous results for four identical bosons, where it was found, both theoreticallyÂ HammerÂ andÂ Platter (2007); von StecherÂ etÂ al. (2009); HadizadehÂ etÂ al. (2011); Deltuva (2011) and experimentallyÂ FerlainoÂ etÂ al. (2009), that there are two lower-lying tetramers associated with the ground-state trimer. The present scenario more closely resembles studies of a light atom resonantly interacting with three identical heavy atomsÂ BlumeÂ andÂ Yan (2014); WangÂ etÂ al. (2012b); SchmicklerÂ etÂ al. (2017). Our findings are generally consistent with the results of these previous works, although no excited tetramer was reported for small mass imbalanceÂ 111We have not investigated tetramer states tied to the excited Efimov trimer, but we expect that they will exist as resonant states embedded in the atom-trimer continuum, as is the case for identical bosonsÂ Deltuva (2011); von Stecher (2011).. Note that, within our theory, we do not require an additional length scale to fix the positions of the tetramers relative to the Efimov trimersÂ HadizadehÂ etÂ al. (2011).

A crucial point is that the few-body physics described here is essentially universal, in the sense that the entire spectrum is independent of the details of the short-range physics. This universality originates from the large separation of scales between the short-distance physics, characterized here by the effective range r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0r_{0}, and the typical size of the ground-state Efimov trimer. The latter may be conveniently characterized by the â€œcriticalâ€ scattering length aâˆ’subscriptğ‘a_{-} at which the trimer crosses into the three-atom continuum. In our model, we have aâˆ’/r0â‰ƒ2467similar-to-or-equalssubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘Ÿ02467a_{-}/r_{0}\simeq 2467Â 222This number had a typo in Ref.Â LevinsenÂ etÂ al. (2015) which did not affect any of the other results of that paper. (see Table 1 for a summary of the length scales and energy scales associated with Efimov physics). This large ratio ensures that the energy of the ground-state Efimov trimer at unitarity is far smaller than that required to probe the short-range physics. Indeed, we see that the ratio of critical scattering lengths for the excited and ground-state trimers, i.e., aâˆ’(1)/aâˆ’â‰ƒ1991similar-to-or-equalssuperscriptsubscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘1991a_{-}^{(1)}/a_{-}\simeq 1991, is very close to the predicted scaling factor of 1986.11986.11986.1. IV Polaron energy at unitarity

We now turn to the many-body system and investigate the zero-temperature equation of state for the polaron at unitarity. Since we wish to properly describe Efimov physics within our models, we will focus on the regime where the boson-boson scattering length aBsubscriptğ‘Ba_{\text{B}} is always much smaller than all other length scales. To test the accuracy of our variational approach outlined in Eqs.Â (4) and (5), we will consider wave functions with up to one, two or three Bogoliubov excitations, corresponding to |Ïˆ0âŸ©+|Ïˆ1âŸ©ketsubscriptğœ“0ketsubscriptğœ“1\left|{\psi_{0}}\right>+\left|{\psi_{1}}\right>, |Ïˆ0âŸ©+|Ïˆ1âŸ©+|Ïˆ2âŸ©ketsubscriptğœ“0ketsubscriptğœ“1ketsubscriptğœ“2\left|{\psi_{0}}\right>+\left|{\psi_{1}}\right>+\left|{\psi_{2}}\right>, and |Î¨âŸ©ketÎ¨\left|{\Psi}\right>, respectively. For each model, we will convert the short-distance scale (e.g., r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0r_{0} or Î›âˆ’1superscriptÎ›1\Lambda^{-1}) into the dimensionless three-body parameter n1/3â€‹|aâˆ’|superscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘n^{1/3}|a_{-}| in order to expose the role of universal Efimov physics. The numerical results are displayed in Fig.Â 2 and, in the following, we analyze the different regimes defined by particle density.

IV.1 Low-density limit

In the limit of vanishing density n1/3â€‹|aâˆ’|â†’0â†’superscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘0n^{1/3}|a_{-}|\to 0, the ground-state polaron energy should reduce to that of the deepest bound few-body cluster. If the polaron variational wave function only includes one Bogoliubov excitation, the largest few-body state it can describe is the dimer, which has zero binding energy at unitarity. Thus, as shown in Fig.Â 2, we obtain an energy that simply tends to zero with decreasing density, i.e., E=âˆ’(4â€‹Ï€â€‹n)2/3/mâ‰ƒâˆ’5.4â€‹n2/3/mğ¸superscript4ğœ‹ğ‘›23ğ‘šsimilar-to-or-equals5.4superscriptğ‘›23ğ‘šE=-(4\pi n)^{2/3}/m\simeq-5.4n^{2/3}/m RathÂ andÂ Schmidt (2013); LiÂ andÂ DasÂ Sarma (2014). Note that this is independent of the microscopic model we use since the interparticle spacing greatly exceeds any length scale of the impurity-boson interactions.

For polaron wave functions with up to two (three) Bogoliubov excitations, the low-density limit recovers the deepest bound universal trimer (tetramer) state discussed in Sec.Â III. Here, the density drops out of the problem and we have polaron energy E=âˆ’Î·mâ€‹|aâˆ’|2ğ¸ğœ‚ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘2E=-\frac{\eta}{m|a_{-}|^{2}}, where Î·ğœ‚\eta is a universal, model-independent constant that depends on the Efimov cluster size (see Fig.Â 2).

We also expect there to be larger bound clusters beyond the tetramer, similarly to the case of identical bosons where larger clusters associated with the Efimov effect have been predictedÂ VonÂ Stecher (2010); GattobigioÂ andÂ Kievsky (2014); YanÂ andÂ Blume (2015) and, indeed, experimentally observedÂ ZenesiniÂ etÂ al. (2013). For the impurity case, recent QMC calculations already demonstrate the existence of a pentamer with Î·â‰ƒ300similar-to-or-equalsğœ‚300\eta\simeq 300Â PeÃ±a ArdilaÂ andÂ Giorgini (2015). However, since there is a high-energy cutoff in the problem (e.g., set by Î›Î›\Lambda or r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0r_{0}), the system cannot support arbitrarily deeply bound Efimov clusters, and the deepest bound state should be universal as long as Î·â‰ª106much-less-thanğœ‚superscript106\eta\ll 10^{6}. Indeed, as suggested by the QMC calculationsÂ PeÃ±a ArdilaÂ andÂ Giorgini (2015), it is possible that there is no bound cluster larger than the pentamer for the equal-mass impurity case. Firstly, the pairwise attraction between the impurity and the bosons scales with Nğ‘N rather than Nâ€‹(Nâˆ’1)ğ‘ğ‘1N(N-1), unlike the case for Nğ‘N identical bosonsÂ GreeneÂ etÂ al. (2017), so larger bound states will be less favored. Secondly, an effective short-range repulsion between bosons could mean that the pentamer has a closed-shell structure, where any additional bosons must occupy higher energy orbitals, similar to what has been argued for mass-imbalanced fermionsÂ BazakÂ andÂ Petrov (2017); Bazak (2017). Such an effective repulsion naturally emerges in both the r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0r_{0}- and the Î›Î›\Lambda-models: In the former, this arises from the fact that only one boson at a time can occupy the closed-channel dimer, while in the latter it is due to the three-body cut-off being equivalent to a three-body repulsionÂ BedaqueÂ etÂ al. (1999).

From the above considerations, it is reasonable to conclude that the low-density limit is universal. Moreover, since there is a maximum size to the deepest bound Efimov cluster, we expect the polaron energy to have a well-defined thermodynamic limit, where mâ€‹E/n2/3ğ‘šğ¸superscriptğ‘›23mE/n^{2/3} is finite for non-zero density.

IV.2 High-density limit

To further support the claim that the polaron energy is finite at unitarity, we consider the opposite limit of high density, nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\to\infty. Here, the interparticle spacing becomes smaller than the range of the interactions and thus the system will depend on the microscopic details of the model. However, in the case of the r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0r_{0}-model, it allows us to perform a controlled perturbative expansion in the inter-channel coupling gğ‘”g (or, equivalently, 1/n1/3â€‹|r0|1superscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘Ÿ01/n^{1/3}|r_{0}|) at unitarityÂ GurarieÂ andÂ Radzihovsky (2007). Physically, this corresponds to the limit of a narrow Feshbach resonance, a scenario which has already been successfully investigated for an impurity in a Fermi sea, both theoreticallyÂ Massignan (2012); TrefzgerÂ andÂ Castin (2012); QiÂ andÂ Zhai (2012) and experimentallyÂ KohstallÂ etÂ al. (2012); CetinaÂ etÂ al. (2016).

Our starting point is the self-energy of the unitary Bose polaron, which, in the limit gâ†’0â†’ğ‘”0g\to 0 and aBâ†’0â†’subscriptğ‘B0a_{\text{B}}\to 0, consists of the lowest order diagrams shown in Fig.Â 3. Such diagrams are included in the self-consistent Tğ‘‡T-matrix approach to the Bose polaronÂ RathÂ andÂ Schmidt (2013). For an impurity with momentum ğ©ğ©{\bf p} and frequency Ï‰ğœ”\omega, the self-energy in this limit is explicitly

In the regime of weak boson-boson interactions, where nâ€‹aB3â‰ªaB/|r0|â‰ª1much-less-thanğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘B3subscriptğ‘Bsubscriptğ‘Ÿ0much-less-than1na_{\text{B}}^{3}\ll a_{\text{B}}/|r_{0}|\ll 1, we obtain the ground-state polaron energy

This demonstrates that the energy is well-defined and bounded from below in this limit, even when the boson-boson interactions are vanishingly small. Such behavior arises from the fact that only one boson at a time can scatter into the closed channel, thus producing an effective boson-boson repulsion that restricts the density of bosons that can cluster around the impurity. As shown in Fig.Â 2, the perturbative expression correctly reproduces the energy for the r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0r_{0}-model in the high-density limit. Note that the one-excitation wave function only captures the leading order term in Fig.Â 3(a), while the wave functions with two or three excitations correctly describe the next order correction in 1/n1/3â€‹|r0|1superscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘Ÿ01/n^{1/3}|r_{0}|.

In the case of the Î›Î›\Lambda-model, the high-density limit corresponds to n1/3/Î›â†’âˆâ†’superscriptğ‘›13Î›n^{1/3}/\Lambda\to\infty, which is equivalent to taking the cutoff Î›Î›\Lambda to zero. Therefore, within our variational approach, only two-body correlations survive and we obtain the equations for the wave function with one excitation (see AppendixÂ A). For vanishing boson-boson interactions, this yields E=âˆ’(4â€‹Ï€â€‹n)2/3/mğ¸superscript4ğœ‹ğ‘›23ğ‘šE=-(4\pi n)^{2/3}/m, which is the polaron energy of the one-excitation wave function across all densities, as shown in Fig.Â 2.

IV.3 Many-body universal regime

In the intermediate regime râ‰ªnâˆ’1/3â‰ª|aâˆ’|much-less-thanğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘›13much-less-thansubscriptğ‘r\ll n^{-1/3}\ll|a_{-}| (where rğ‘Ÿr can represent |r0|subscriptğ‘Ÿ0|r_{0}| or Î›âˆ’1superscriptÎ›1\Lambda^{-1}), the interparticle distance is well separated from all length scales associated with the interactions. If the medium were fermionic rather than bosonic, then the polaron energy at unitarity would be a universal value that only depends on the medium density, i.e., Epolâ‰ƒâˆ’4.6â€‹n2/3/msimilar-to-or-equalssubscriptğ¸pol4.6superscriptğ‘›23ğ‘šE_{\rm pol}\simeq-4.6n^{2/3}/mÂ Chevy (2006). Remarkably, for the Bose polaron, we see in Fig.Â 2 that the energy strongly depends on n1/3â€‹|aâˆ’|superscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘n^{1/3}|a_{-}| at intermediate densities. This suggests that there exist resonant three-body interactions, such that there are strong three-body correlations in the system even when the trimer binding energy is comparatively small.

Even though the energy of the Bose polaron cannot be assigned a universal value at unitarity, we argue that it is, in fact, a universal function of n1/3â€‹|aâˆ’|superscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘n^{1/3}|a_{-}| away from the high-density regime. We have previously argued that the low-density limit of the polaron energy universally depends on n1/3â€‹|aâˆ’|superscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘n^{1/3}|a_{-}| due to the universal behavior of the few-body states demonstrated in Sec.Â III. Here, for the intermediate density regime shown in Fig.Â 4, we see that different microscopic models of the Bose polaron can essentially be collapsed onto the same curve when the ground-state energy is plotted versus n1/3â€‹|aâˆ’|superscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘n^{1/3}|a_{-}|. In particular, both the results for the Î›Î›\Lambda- and the r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0r_{0}-models are consistent with the QMC calculation from Ref.Â PeÃ±a ArdilaÂ andÂ Giorgini (2016) when Eq.Â (11) is used to plot the QMC data in terms of the Efimov three-body parameter. This demonstrates that the polaron energy can be universally described in terms of n01/3â€‹|aâˆ’|superscriptsubscriptğ‘›013subscriptğ‘n_{0}^{1/3}|a_{-}|, regardless of the microscopic details. Furthermore, it suggests that our variational approach with three Bogoliubov excitations captures the dominant correlations in the full many-body problem, and that the Efimov three-body parameter plays a more important role in the polaron energy than the coherence length of the condensate (see AppendixÂ B). We emphasize that our comparison in Fig.Â 4 constitutes a complete reinterpretation of the QMC results of Ref.Â PeÃ±a ArdilaÂ andÂ Giorgini (2016), since that work did not consider the possibility that the variation of the polaron energy with boson-boson interaction was due to Efimov physics.

V Characterization of the polaron

Having shown that the polaron energy is a universal function of n1/3â€‹|aâˆ’|superscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘n^{1/3}|a_{-}| for sufficiently low densities, we now turn to the other quasiparticle properties which characterize the polaron: the residue, effective mass, and contact. We will generally focus on the r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0r_{0}-model, which is the more physical model and which allows a perturbative analysis in the high-density limit.

V.1 Residue

The residue Zğ‘Z is the squared overlap of the polaron wave function with the non-interacting state c0â€ â€‹|Î¦âŸ©superscriptsubscriptğ‘0â€ ketÎ¦c_{0}^{\dagger}\left|{\Phi}\right>. Making reference to the wave function in Eq.Â (5), this is

Z=|Î±0|2,ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ›¼02\displaystyle Z=|\alpha_{0}|^{2}, (14)

where we assume âŸ¨Î¨|Î¨âŸ©=1inner-productÎ¨Î¨1\left<\Psi|\Psi\right>=1 for normalization (see AppendixÂ C). The residue can be accessed directly in experiment; indeed, in the case of the Fermi polaron it has been measured using both radio-frequency spectroscopyÂ SchirotzekÂ etÂ al. (2009) and Rabi oscillationsÂ KohstallÂ etÂ al. (2012).

In Fig.Â 5 we show our results for the polaron residue at unitarity as a function of the three-body parameter, where the boson-boson interactions are taken to be vanishingly small. We find that there are clear differences between the results depending on the number of Bogoliubov excitations used in the variational approach, and also between the different models. Within the r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0r_{0}-model the residue takes the value 1/2 in the high-density regime where the polaron wave function is an equal superposition of the impurity and the closed-channel dimer. However, while the residue within the one-excitation approximation is seen to increase from 1/2 to 2/3 with increasing density, we observe a rapid decrease of Zğ‘Z towards the low-density regime when including several excitations. On the other hand, for the Î›Î›\Lambda-model, the residue is 2/3 if we consider only one Bogoliubov excitation. By increasing the number of Bogoliubov excitations, it is suppressed not only in the few-body dominated regime, but also in the high-density limit, where the residue takes the values 1/3 and 1/9, respectively, when two and three excitations are taken into account. Thus, unlike the energy, the polaron residue does not appear to converge to a universal function of the three-body parameter.

The origin of this behavior can be understood within perturbation theory for the r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0r_{0}-model in the high-density limit. Considering again the diagrams in Fig.Â 3 and the explicit expression for the self-energy in Eq.Â (12), we find at small gğ‘”g:

Zâˆ’1superscriptğ‘1\displaystyle Z^{-1} =1âˆ’âˆ‚Î£â€‹(ğŸ,Ï‰)âˆ‚Ï‰|Ï‰=Eabsent1evaluated-atÎ£0ğœ”ğœ”ğœ”ğ¸\displaystyle=1-\left.\frac{\partial\Sigma({\bf 0},\omega)}{\partial\omega}\right|_{\omega=E}
â‰ƒ2âˆ’37â€‹2(8â€‹Ï€â€‹nâ€‹|r0|3)1/4+L|r0|,similar-to-or-equalsabsent2372superscript8ğœ‹ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ0314ğ¿subscriptğ‘Ÿ0\displaystyle\simeq 2-\sqrt{\frac{3}{7}}\frac{2}{(8\pi n|r_{0}|^{3})^{1/4}}+\frac{L}{|r_{0}|}, (15)

where Lğ¿L is a low-energy length scale that provides an infrared cutoff of low momenta. In the thermodynamic limit, this is set by the coherence length of the BEC, i.e., we have LâˆÎ¾proportional-toğ¿ğœ‰L\propto\xi. Thus, we find that the residue vanishes when the coherence length Î¾â†’âˆâ†’ğœ‰\xi\to\infty, and consequently the polaron wave function is orthogonal to the non-interacting impurity state in the case of an ideal BEC. This feature cannot properly be captured within our variational approach, since this requires an infinite number of Bogoliubov excitations; hence the observed lack of convergence in Fig.Â 5. On the other hand, when aBâ‰ 0subscriptğ‘B0a_{\text{B}}\neq 0 we find that the wave functions with two and three excitations both give the same leading order correction to Zğ‘Z:

Zâˆ’12âˆaB|r0|,proportional-toğ‘12subscriptğ‘Bsubscriptğ‘Ÿ0\displaystyle Z-\frac{1}{2}\propto\sqrt{\frac{a_{\text{B}}}{|r_{0}|}}, (16)

in the limit n1/3â€‹aBâ‰ª1much-less-thansuperscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘B1n^{1/3}a_{\text{B}}\ll 1 and n1/3â€‹|r0|â†’âˆâ†’superscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘Ÿ0n^{1/3}|r_{0}|\to\infty 555The high-density expansion for Zğ‘Z at finite aBsubscriptğ‘Ba_{\text{B}} can, in principle, be calculated using an approach similar to that in Ref.Â ChristensenÂ etÂ al. (2015). However, such a lengthy perturbative analysis goes beyond the scope of this work.. Thus, in this case, the residue is finite and initially increases with decreasing |r0|subscriptğ‘Ÿ0|r_{0}|. Note, however, that the residue always vanishes in the low-density regime, as shown in Fig.Â 5, since the polaron evolves into a few-body bound state which has zero overlap with the non-interacting impurity state.

The simultaneous convergence of the energy but suppression of the residue in the ideal BEC arises from the fact that the impurity affects the condensate at arbitrarily large distances and thus excites an infinite number of low-energy modes in the condensate. This result is akin to the orthogonality catastrophe for a static impurity in a Fermi gas. Indeed, in that case, the orthogonality of the interacting and non-interacting impurity wave functions is also apparent in perturbation theory, already at lowest order beyond mean-field theoryÂ Anderson (1995). We also note that the vanishing residue of the Bose polaron is not confined to the strongly interacting impurity at unitarity: Even for weak impurity-boson interactions, the residue of the attractive polaron was found within perturbation theory to approach zero as 1/Î¾1ğœ‰1/\xi when aBâ†’0â†’subscriptğ‘B0a_{\text{B}}\to 0Â ChristensenÂ etÂ al. (2015).

V.2 Effective mass

The interactions between the impurity and the bosonic medium also modify the mobility of the impurity and give rise to an effective mass mâˆ—superscriptğ‘šm^{*}. This can be derived from the impurityâ€™s self-energy as follows:

mmâˆ—ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘š\displaystyle\frac{m}{m^{*}} =Zâ€‹[1+mâ€‹âˆ‚2Î£â€‹(ğª,E)âˆ‚q2|q=0].absentğ‘delimited-[]1evaluated-atğ‘šsuperscript2Î£ğªğ¸superscriptğ‘2ğ‘0\displaystyle=Z\left[1+m\left.\frac{\partial^{2}\Sigma({\bf q},E)}{\partial q^{2}}\right|_{q=0}\right]. (17)

Note that this gives mâˆ—=msuperscriptğ‘šğ‘šm^{*}=m for the non-interacting impurity state, as required. Our calculation of mâˆ—superscriptğ‘šm^{*} within the variational approach is described in AppendixÂ C, and the results for aBâ†’0â†’subscriptğ‘B0a_{\text{B}}\to 0 at unitarity are plotted in Fig.Â 6. Due to the complexity of the calculation, we restrict ourselves to wave functions with up to two Bogoliubov excitations.

For the case of an ideal BEC, we have residue Zâ†’0â†’ğ‘0Z\to 0, and thus one might conclude from Eq.Â (17) that the effective mass diverges. However, if we once again consider the high-density limit of the r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0r_{0}-model and use the self-energy in Eq.Â (12), we obtain

mmâˆ—ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘š\displaystyle\frac{m}{m^{*}} â‰ƒZâ€‹(32âˆ’37â€‹1(8â€‹Ï€â€‹nâ€‹|r0|3)1/4+Î±â€‹L|r0|),similar-to-or-equalsabsentğ‘32371superscript8ğœ‹ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ0314ğ›¼ğ¿subscriptğ‘Ÿ0\displaystyle\simeq Z\left(\frac{3}{2}-\sqrt{\frac{3}{7}}\frac{1}{(8\pi n|r_{0}|^{3})^{1/4}}+\alpha\frac{L}{|r_{0}|}\right), (18)

where Î±ğ›¼\alpha is a constant that must be determined from a proper finite-aBsubscriptğ‘Ba_{\text{B}} perturbative analysis. Thus, we see that there is a term proportional to Lğ¿L that cancels the corresponding term in the residue in Eq.Â (15), implying that the effective mass is finite.

Indeed, in the low-density few-body regime, we already have the situation where the residue vanishes, while the effective mass remains finite with mâˆ—=(N+1)â€‹msuperscriptğ‘šğ‘1ğ‘šm^{*}=(N+1)m, where Nğ‘N is the number of bosons bound to to the impurity. This behavior is captured by both r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0r_{0}- and Î›Î›\Lambda-models, as shown in Fig.Â 6, where the wave function with two Bogoliubov excitations has mâˆ—/mâ†’3â†’superscriptğ‘šğ‘š3m^{*}/m\to 3 as nâ†’0â†’ğ‘›0n\to 0. Likewise, we expect the wave function with three excitations to recover the mass of the tetramer in this limit. For higher densities, we find that the results of our variational approach become sensitive to the specific model used, as well as to the number of excitations of the ideal BEC considered. Here, in the many-body limit, one requires an infinite number of low-energy excitations to correctly describe the effective mass for aBâ†’0â†’subscriptğ‘B0a_{\text{B}}\to 0, similarly to the case of the residue.

For a BEC with 0<n1/3â€‹aBâ‰ª10superscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘Bmuch-less-than10<n^{1/3}a_{\text{B}}\ll 1, the behavior of the effective mass in the high-density limit of the r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0r_{0}-model can once again be captured using just two Bogoliubov excitations of the BEC. In the limit |r0|â†’âˆâ†’subscriptğ‘Ÿ0|r_{0}|\to\infty, the polaron effective mass mâˆ—/mâ†’4/3â†’superscriptğ‘šğ‘š43m^{*}/m\to 4/3, which corresponds to twice the reduced mass of the impurity and closed-channel dimer. Moreover, we find that the leading order correction behaves as

mmâˆ—âˆ’34âˆaB|r0|.proportional-toğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘š34subscriptğ‘Bsubscriptğ‘Ÿ0\displaystyle\frac{m}{m^{*}}-\frac{3}{4}\propto\sqrt{\frac{a_{\text{B}}}{|r_{0}|}}. (19)

Thus, the effective mass in this case initially decreases with decreasing density, before increasing towards the mass of the deepest bound few-body cluster.

V.3 Contact

Another quantity of interest is the unitary Tan contact, which is defined from the polaron energy asÂ Tan (2008a); *Tan_2008b; *Tan_2008c; BraatenÂ etÂ al. (2008)

Cğ¶\displaystyle C =m2â€‹g2â€‹âˆ‚Eâˆ‚Î½|Î½=0.absentevaluated-atsuperscriptğ‘š2superscriptğ‘”2ğ¸ğœˆğœˆ0\displaystyle=m^{2}g^{2}\left.\frac{\partial E}{\partial\nu}\right|_{\nu=0}. (20)

Physically, the contact gives a measure of the density of pairs at short distances. For the two-channel Hamiltonian in Eq.Â (II), one can show that the contact is proportional to the population of closed-channel dimersÂ BraatenÂ etÂ al. (2008):

(22)

Note that the limit gâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘”g\to\infty is well defined, and thus this expression also captures the single-channel Î›Î›\Lambda-model.

Figure 7 displays the contact at unitarity for both Î›Î›\Lambda- and r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0r_{0}-models in the case of vanishing boson-boson interactions. Similarly to the polaron energy, we find that the contact in the high-density limit is well converged with respect to the number of Bogoliubov excitations. For the r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0r_{0}-model, we can evaluate the contact perturbatively for large n1/3â€‹|r0|superscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘Ÿ0n^{1/3}|r_{0}| using the self-energy in Eq.Â (12). Here we simply shift the closed-channel dispersion from Ïµğ©dsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ©ğ‘‘\epsilon_{\bf p}^{d} to Ïµğ©d+Î½superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ©ğ‘‘ğœˆ\epsilon_{\bf p}^{d}+\nu and then determine the ground-state energy from the equation E=Î£â€‹(ğŸ,E)ğ¸Î£0ğ¸E=\Sigma({\bf 0},E) as a function of detuning Î½ğœˆ\nu. Applying Eq.Â (20) then yields the high-density expression

Câ‰ƒ8â€‹Ï€|r0|â€‹(12âˆ’2928â€‹37â€‹1(8â€‹Ï€â€‹nâ€‹|r0|3)1/4).similar-to-or-equalsğ¶8ğœ‹subscriptğ‘Ÿ0122928371superscript8ğœ‹ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ0314\displaystyle C\simeq\frac{8\pi}{|r_{0}|}\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{29}{28}\sqrt{\frac{3}{7}}\frac{1}{(8\pi n|r_{0}|^{3})^{1/4}}\right). (23)

We find that this perturbative result is correctly reproduced by both two- and three-excitation approximations in the high-density limit. The leading order term is independent of density since the closed-channel fraction tends to 1/2121/2 at unitarity as |r0|â†’âˆâ†’subscriptğ‘Ÿ0|r_{0}|\to\infty (or, equivalently, as gâ†’0â†’ğ‘”0g\to 0), see Eq.Â (15).

For lower densities n1/3â€‹|aâˆ’|â‰²103less-than-or-similar-tosuperscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘superscript103n^{1/3}|a_{-}|\lesssim 10^{3}, the contact becomes insensitive to the underlying model and thus appears to be a universal function of the dimensionless three-body parameter (see Fig.Â 7). In the limit of vanishing density nâ†’0â†’ğ‘›0n\to 0, we recover the contact of the deepest bound few-body cluster, where Câ€‹|aâˆ’|ğ¶subscriptğ‘C|a_{-}| is a universal number.

VI Conclusions and outlook

Using a variational approach, we have investigated the ground state of the Bose polaron with unitarity limited impurity-boson interactions. For sufficiently low boson densities, we have demonstrated that the polaron equation of state is a universal function of the three-body parameter associated with Efimov physics. This is a highly non-trivial result, since the regime of universality extends to densities at which the binding energies of the few-body states are several orders of magnitude smaller than the polaron energy. Our findings are corroborated by the fact that we observe the same behavior for two different microscopic models, and by the fact that our calculations agree well with recent QMC resultsÂ PeÃ±a ArdilaÂ andÂ Giorgini (2015, 2016) when they are appropriately reinterpreted in terms of the three-body parameter. We have also demonstrated that the few-body spectrum of Efimov trimers and associated tetramers is model independent, further highlighting the universality of our results.

In the non-universal, high-density limit, we have performed a controlled perturbative analysis of the r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0r_{0}-model and we have derived new analytic expressions for the unitary Bose polaron at a narrow Feshbach resonance. Our results demonstrate that even when we take the ideal Bose gas limit, the polaron energy and contact can remain well defined thermodynamically. This is a consequence of the fact that only one boson at a time can occupy the closed-channel dimer state, which thus generates an effective repulsion between bosons that acts to stabilize the system. We expect a similar scenario for the Î›Î›\Lambda-model since the high-momentum cut-off in the three- and four-body terms of the variational equations is equivalent to an explicit three-body repulsionÂ BedaqueÂ etÂ al. (1999). However, in general, it is not clear that a well-defined thermodynamic limit exists for treatments of the Bose polaron that focus on single-channel Hamiltonians and neglect Efimov physicsÂ ShchadilovaÂ etÂ al. (2016b); GrusdtÂ etÂ al. (2017).

While the polaron equation of state at unitarity is relatively insensitive to boson-boson interactions, we find that the quasiparticle residue and effective mass strongly depend on the coherence length of the BEC. In particular, the residue vanishes as Î¾â†’âˆâ†’ğœ‰\xi\to\infty, a feature which resembles the orthogonality catastropheÂ Anderson (1967). Thus, an interesting remaining question is how the residue tends to zero with the number of excitations of the condensate included in the wave function. A related question is: what finite result does the effective mass converge towards as Î¾â†’âˆâ†’ğœ‰\xi\to\infty and is it a universal function of the three-body parameter?

We emphasize that the (two-channel) r0subscriptğ‘Ÿ0r_{0}-model faithfully describes the physics of an actual Feshbach resonance in an ultracold atomic gasÂ TimmermansÂ etÂ al. (1999), and thus we expect our results to accurately describe current and future cold atom experiments. Furthermore, we expect the universal behavior presented here to also exist for heavy impurities, a scenario which can be realized by choosing atomic species with a large mass ratio or by pinning the impurity in an optical lattice. In the particular case of a static impurity, there are no Efimov few-body states, and therefore it would be of great interest to understand how the system behaves in the limit n1/3â€‹|r0|â‰ª1much-less-thansuperscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘Ÿ01n^{1/3}|r_{0}|\ll 1 of the two-channel model.

Our results may be probed in experiments similar to those carried out recently at JILAÂ HuÂ etÂ al. (2016) and in AarhusÂ JÃ¸rgensenÂ etÂ al. (2016). In particular, our results directly apply to the latter experiment which used 39K as both the impurity and host atoms. Furthermore, we estimate that n1/3â€‹|aâˆ’|â‰ƒ100similar-to-or-equalssuperscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘100n^{1/3}|a_{-}|\simeq 100 in that experiment, which indicates that it is already in a regime where the non-trivial dependendence on the interparticle spacing is strongly pronounced. Indeed, in a recent JILA experiementÂ KlaussÂ etÂ al. (2017), the density of the Bose gas was changed by two orders of magnitude, and thus an experimental investigation of the density dependence of the unitary Bose polaron appears well within reach.

Appendix B Effect of finite coherence length and number of Bogoliubov excitations

In SectionÂ IV.3 we compared the results of our variational approach with those obtained in quantum Monte Carlo calculations by PeÃ±a Ardila and GiorginiÂ PeÃ±a ArdilaÂ andÂ Giorgini (2016), and found very good agreement across more than an order of magnitude in interparticle spacing, see Fig.Â 2. In this comparison we highlighted the fact that the dependence of the polaron energy on the three-body parameter aâˆ’subscriptğ‘a_{-} is much stronger than the dependence on aBsubscriptğ‘Ba_{\text{B}}, and to emphasize this we took aB=0subscriptğ‘B0a_{\text{B}}=0. However, as we have argued in SectionÂ III, in the QMC calculation the ratio between aâˆ’subscriptğ‘a_{-} and aBsubscriptğ‘Ba_{\text{B}} was kept fixed at a value of aâˆ’(QMC)â‰ƒâˆ’2.09â€‹(36)Ã—104â€‹aB(QMC)similar-to-or-equalssuperscriptsubscriptğ‘QMC2.0936superscript104superscriptsubscriptğ‘BQMCa_{-}^{\mathrm{{\scriptscriptstyle(QMC)}}}\simeq-2.09(36)\times 10^{4}a_{\text{B}}^{\rm{\scriptscriptstyle(QMC)}} as identified in Eq.Â (11). Therefore, we now consider the residual effect of keeping aâˆ’/aBsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘Ba_{-}/a_{\text{B}} fixed in the same manner as in the QMC. Our results for the polaron energy within the Î›Î›\Lambda-model are shown in Fig.Â 8. We see that the polaron energy is almost unaffected in the low-density, few-body dominated regime, while aBsubscriptğ‘Ba_{\text{B}} becomes more important with increasing density. However, throughout the range plotted, i.e., the universal many-body regime, the relative change in energy arising from the change in n1/3â€‹|aâˆ’|superscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘n^{1/3}|a_{-}| clearly greatly exceeds that from the increase in n1/3â€‹aBsuperscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘Bn^{1/3}a_{\text{B}}. We furthermore see that both sets of results are consistent with our reinterpretation of the QMC results in terms of a three-body parameter.

In the inset of Fig.Â 8 we furthermore illustrate the convergence of the polaron energy as a function of (inverse) number of Bogoliubov excitations included in our variational approach. In the many-body dominated regime, at n1/3â€‹|aâˆ’|=500superscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘500n^{1/3}|a_{-}|=500, we see that the convergence appears to be nearly linear, with a slope (and extrapolation to an infinite number of excitations) that is consistent with the difference between the finite aBsubscriptğ‘Ba_{\text{B}} dotted line and the QMC results in the main figure. Closer to the few-body dominated regime at n1/3â€‹|aâˆ’|=100superscriptğ‘›13subscriptğ‘100n^{1/3}|a_{-}|=100 our approach converges more slowly due to the strong few-body correlations induced by the trimer and tetramer bound states. However, it is likely that including four Bogoliubov excitations in our approach to account for the hypothesized pentamer (see Sec.Â IV.1) would yield a nearly converged result.

C.1 Effective mass

For a system with rotational symmetry, the inverse effective mass is defined as

1mâˆ—=âˆ‚2Eâ€‹(P)âˆ‚P2,1superscriptğ‘šsuperscript2ğ¸ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘ƒ2\displaystyle\frac{1}{m^{*}}=\frac{\partial^{2}E(P)}{\partial P^{2}}, (36)

where Eâ€‹(P)ğ¸ğ‘ƒE(P) is the energy dispersion of the Bose polaron. The variational ansatz can be easily extended to a Bose polaron with a finite momentum, but solving the resulting integral equations becomes numerically expensive because the equations do not have rotational symmetry. Here, following a similar line of argument to Ref.Â TrefzgerÂ andÂ Castin (2012), we present a method to calculate the effective mass without solving the integral equations for a finite-momentum Bose polaron.

In general, the coupled integral equations for Î³ğ›¾\gammaâ€™s for a finite momentum polaron have the following structure (similar to Eqs.Â (24-27)):

While the matrix X^^ğ‘‹\hat{X} is not the Hamiltonian, it is still Hermitian. The energy dispersion Eâ€‹(P)ğ¸ğ‘ƒE(P) is determined by the zero-crossing of the lowest (or highest, depending on the sign convention) eigenvalue of X^^ğ‘‹\hat{X}.
